componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the PPL Corporation Fourth Quarter Conference Call. [Operator instructions] I would now turn the conference over to Joe Bergstein, Director of Investor Relation.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining the PPL conference call on fourth quarter results and our general business outlook. We're providing slides of this presentation on our website at www.pplweb.com. Any statements made in this presentation about future ope
componenttext: Good morning. Thank you for joining the PPL conference call on fourth quarter results and our general business outlook. We're providing slides of this presentation on our website at www.pplweb.com. Any statements made in this presentation about future operating results or other future events are forward-looking statements under the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from such forward-looking statements. A discussion of the factors that could cause actual results or events to vary is contained in the appendix to this presentation and in the companyâ€™s SEC filings. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Jim Miller, PPL Chairman, President and CEO.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe, and good morning, everyone on the call. We've got a lot to cover today, so we'll jump right into it. Today, we planned to discuss our 2010 results and our 2011 earnings forecast, as well as provide you with a more in-depth discussion of the s
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe, and good morning, everyone on the call. We've got a lot to cover today, so we'll jump right into it. Today, we planned to discuss our 2010 results and our 2011 earnings forecast, as well as provide you with a more in-depth discussion of the strength of our platform that we feel is in well positioned, I should say to grow share in our value over the next two years. 
Obviously, the past few years have been a challenging for our sector, especially those with significant competitive generation. At PPL, we've used this period as an opportunity to strengthen our business mix and focus capital on the rate regulated sector of our industry. As a result, we've reduced our earnings risk profile and retained the upside inherent to our supply business when wholesale electricity markets recover from our current down cycle. We already see proof that the steps we've taken over the past few years have significantly strengthened our company while improving our flexibility to thrive in a variety of market scenarios. This morning, we'll provide you with our normal year-end update and also discuss our 2011 earnings forecast.
Bill Spence, our Chief Operating Officer will provide you with a detailed operational overview and Paul Farr, Chief Financial Officer will review the financial details with you. And of course we'll leave time for your questions at the end. 
Before launching into the discussion, I would like to talk briefly about some recent M&A trait press rumors mentioning P&L. You're all aware to our long standing and appropriate policy not to discuss market rumors or speculations, and we won't deviate from that today. As we've said many times before, the company continuously explores opportunities to enhance value whether it be acquisitions, divestitures, improved operations of our existing businesses. There's something to discuss in regards to one of those potential opportunities, we do it when the time is appropriate. So until that time comes, we'll not respond to questions on that matter today. Now let's move onto the earnings announcement we've made this morning.
Driven by a strong fourth quarter, we ended the year with reported earnings of $2.17 per share and ongoing earnings of $3.13 per share. These results are higher than our most recent forecast range even excluding the $0.12 share contribution from the Kentucky operations, which were not included in our prior forecast. 
Considering the continued headwinds of very low wholesale electricity prices driven by low natural gas prices, we're very pleased with our 2010 results. Fully factoring in dilution from the E.ON U.S. acquisition, our 2010 earnings from ongoing operations are 60% higher than our 2009 results. While the combination of our very beneficial hedging profile and depressed energy and capacity prices results in a lower earnings per share forecast for 2011 than we achieved in 2010, we expect strong growth in our utility segments in the future.
This earnings growth is based on immediate infrastructure improvements in these companies, which will result in significant rate base growth over the next several years. We expect compound annual rate base growth of our combined regulated businesses to be approximately 9.5% from 2011 to 2015. We're confident in our ability to earn reasonable returns on this rate base because these utilities are best-in-class performance and they operate in jurisdictions with highly constructive regulatory frameworks. Also, support not to overlook the superb competitive generation assets that we have in the mid-Atlantic region and in Montana. While margins have fallen because of lowering natural gas and capacity pricing, our units continue to be among the most competitive in the PJM Interconnection.
This position has been enhanced by a significant environmental investments that have already been made in our co-units and the investments to expand capacity in our nuclear and hydro units. Our diverse mix of coal, natural gas fired hydro and nuclear generation in this region means that we are well-positioned to benefit from proposed EPA regulations.
In Montana, our balanced portfolio of coal-fired and hydro electric generation puts us in a very good competitive position. As I alluded to earlier, we're confident that prices will eventually rebound, and we do begin to see some industrial growth throughout our territories. When they do, our shareholders will benefit significantly. Our strategic actions for the past year have strengthened our financial position, increasing the proportionate the size of our regulated business and lowering our exposure to commodity market volatility. 
Today, we're announcing that earnings forecast for 2011 is $2.40 to $2.60 per share and Paul will walk you through the major year-on-year drivers in his prepared remarks. Within the forecast, I'd like to highlight that we're projecting 50% of our 2011 earnings will come from our regulated businesses, a substantial increase over 2010. We've also tightened our range compared with previous earnings forecast, reflecting the higher mix of rate regulated businesses and my confidence in PPL's ability to execute in our business plan.
Beyond the excellence assets that we have in place to grow shareholder value, we also have some significant strength that differentiate us from our peers in the sector. In each of the jurisdictions in which we operate, we have strong regulatory relationships built on foundations of transparency and meeting the commitments we make. We expect in value the role the regulators play in ensuring reliable electricity and gas services at reasonable prices while providing a fair return to share owners. Our communicative cooperative approach has led us to a mutual respect among PPL reps and regulators, a respect that makes us a credible voice in the policymaking process. Our regulated companies are among the best in terms of cost competitiveness, reliability and customer service, earning very high customer satisfaction and regulatory recognition.
We intend to retain that distinction by making necessary and prudent investments that will maintain our strong reliability and customer service. In the U.K., for example, we're recognized as an efficiency and customer service leader, benchmarks by which others are judged. This commitment is operational excellence also incorporates disciplined cost management practices to ensure that we're getting the most out of the money we spend.
At the heart of our success, our 14,000 highly trained dedicated employees in our business. We rely on these expert to deliver on the promises that we make to our customers and shareholders. Finally, we're clearly remaining committed to a strong dividend, which we view as a key element of total shareholder return. Our acquisition this past year fortified our dividend and the rate base growth potential that Bill will discuss in a minute. I think this clearly puts us in a much stronger position to grow the dividend in the future. With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Bill for our business and operational review.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to review four of our key business segments with a focus on the value drivers for each one. I believe you'll see that PPL has a compelling growth story in each of our regulated businesses, and we h
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Today, I'm going to review four of our key business segments with a focus on the value drivers for each one. I believe you'll see that PPL has a compelling growth story in each of our regulated businesses, and we have a highly competitive generation fleet that is very well-positioned. Jim mentioned that our regulated growth and rate base is now estimated at a compound annual growth rate of 9.5% over the next five years. That's a full 2% higher than we had previously forecast. 
Now let's turn to Slide 9 and start with an overview of LG&E and KU, which forms our largest regulated business segment. Going forward, we will refer to this segment as the Kentucky regulated segment. The segment consists of two vertically integrated utilities, LG&E, is a gas and electric utility while KU is electric only. Our regulated generation fleet has a capacity of about 8,100 megawatts, with the recent addition of the Trimble County II Coal Plant. LG&E and KU commissioned this 800 megawatt plant in January at a cost of just over $1,500 per KBW. This is an exceptionally low cost for state-of-the-art facility like this.
Like our other regulated operations, LG&E and KU have a history of outstanding customer satisfaction and efficient reliable and safe operations. Brian [ph] and his team have earned the trust and respect of regulators where they have constructive and supportive working relationships. The combination of efficient and effective operations and this constructive regulatory environment have resulted in these utilities having some of the lowest rates in the nation. These rates are a significant economic development tool for our service territories as well. The growth prospects driven by this economic development, coupled with pending changes in EPA environmental regulations will lead to further growth the rate base and returns on that investment. 
As noted on Slide 10, the Kentucky environmental cost recovery mechanism or ECR is provided by a statute enacted in Kentucky in 1992. It allows your near realtime recovery of cost associated with environmental compliance for coal-fired generation. Currently, about 85% of the applicable environmental costs, including investment and operating costs are being recovered through the ECR. Since inception, over $2.9 billion of environmental capital spending, including [ph] have been recovered through the FECR mechanism. The remaining 15% of environmental cost represent the cost associated or allocated to all system sales, sales to Virginia retail customers and sales to Kentucky municipal utility served by KU under FERC approved, full requirements contract. These remaining costs are recoverable through general rate cases. 
As you know, increased regulations being issued and proposed by the EPA are expected to impact coal-fired generation. We expect the majority of our compliance cost in Kentucky will be recovered through the ECR mechanism. The tenant upon final EPR regulations and our valuation of the lease cost options, we believe the various compliance cost for air and coal combustion residuals, CCRs could be more than $2 billion over the next five years. This estimate is not assuming hazardous definition for CCR nor does it include any incremental cost associated with CO2 compliance or new water quality standards. Our estimate will continue to be refined as regulation and lease cost compliance analysis are finalized.
Slide 11 summarizes the environmental control equipment already installed on our coal plants in Kentucky. As you can see, significant environmental controls are already installed at these plants. But we do expect additional investment will be needed to comply with the evolving environmental regulations. LG&E and KU's rate base has grown by more than 50% over the past five years with the construction of Thermal Country II and the installation of scrubbers at KU's Browne and Gen plants. As you can see from this slide, we expect a similar increase over the next five years.
We show environmental CapEx in two categories. We expect the spending designated by the orange bar to be needed regardless of the outcome of the new EPA regulation. The green bar represents the $2 billion estimated to comply with new and proposed EPA regulations, as I mentioned earlier. Since the majority of the environmental CapEx should be recovered through the ECR mechanism, the remainder of environmental and non-environmental CapEx in our group will drive the need for future rate cases.
As agreed in the Kentucky change of control proceeding, new base rates can not be effective prior to January 1, 2013. We are able to offset regulatory lag to a degree using mechanisms that supplement traditional rate cases, and we believe our rates will remain competitive and light a similar activity at surrounding utilities in our favorable starting position. PPL continues to be very pleased with the addition of the newly acquired Kentucky operations, the rate base growth potential, transparent regulatory construct and economic prospects in the Kentucky region will provide earnings growth for this business well into the future.
Before turning to WPD, I'd like to comment briefly on the integration process. The significant amount of upfront work went into ensuring a smooth transition upon closing. Our day one integration work went extremely well, and we will continue to pursue ways to operate the combined business in an efficient manner and within our regulatory commitments. 
Now let's turn to Slide 14 for a review of WPD.  Our WPD business is regulated by the U.K. Office of Gas and Electricity Markets or Ofgem. The U.K. enjoys a fully developed mature electricity market. The regulatory framework is well established and provides a favorable efficient system where WPD has tried for many years. Ofgem has approved a $2 billion expenditure program and the current five-year distribution price control review period, DPCR5 to fund maintenance, capital improvements and upgrades to WPD's network. This approved network investment is 31% higher than that provided in the last price control period.
A key element of the regulation is a multiyear formula rate nature of revenue determination. There is no regulatory lag in expenditures over the entire price control period. They are fully factored into the determination of WPD's revenues during this regulatory cycle. Another key feature of the regulatory construct is the incentive nature of the scheme, whereby companies that are front tier performers can outperform peers on a revenue and ROE basis. Beyound the base revenues, each distribution network operator has the opportunity to earn incentive revenues related to performance and customer service, reliability and cost efficiencies, areas in which WPD has excelled.
We expect that our regulated asset value will increase from $2.8 billion at the end of 2010 to almost $3.5 billion by 2015, driven by the network investments I just mentioned. A key component of last year's price control review was recognition of WPD's readership in the area of operational performance. As shown here, we lead the industry with the lowest number of customer complaints, best contact center performance, best capital unit cost and customer reliability. In fact, the degree to which WPD excelled in these areas, lead the U.K. regulator to increase WPD's revenues by over $240 million in recent future rate periods. This type of best-in-class service is nothing new to WPD. During the last price control review, WPD was awarded over $100 million in incentive revenues.
And finally for international, as of November EEI Conference, we committed to provide modeling parameters for WPD when we announced the 2011 guidance. As the basis for helping model the U.K. operations, we thought that using this segment, P&L format already available to you in our published financials statements would be the best option. 
So let's begin with revenues, which are projected to increase by an average of 6.9% per year plus inflation for the balance of the price control review period. Most of our operating cost increase with inflation although depreciation expense increase at a higher rate due to the levels of CapEx. Pension expenses expected to increase from GBP 20 million in 2011 to GBP 55 million in 2012 and beyond, primarily due to projected amortization of prior actuarial losses. For calculating interest expense, most of our debt is fixed, expect for about 20% that is inflation linked. And over the longer term, our consolidated effective tax rate is expected to be about 25%. With these factors and applying for foreign currency rate, you should be able to more accurately model the inherent growth in WPD's future earnings contribution. 
In summary, the goal for the international segment is to continue to add value for shareholders to frontier performance and customer service and business efficiency, achieving significant growth in rate base and being a source of growing earnings and cash flow for PPL. 
Now let's move on to our Pennsylvania regulated segments starting on Slide 19. Like our Kentucky and WPD operations, PPL Electric Utilities is also known for its superior customer service and well-established constructive regulatory relationships in Pennsylvania. We have very visible investment opportunities with rate base growth projected to rise from $3 billion to $4.8 billion, a 60% increase over the next five years. In fact, we expect to make sustainable investments over the next 10 years to replace aging infrastructure largely built in the 1960s and 1970s, a good portion of which is now starting to reach the end of its usual life. 
On the transmission side of our business, our projected CapEx investment of $1.9 billion through 2015 is nearly 5x higher than the prior five years. As you know, our transmission business operates under an attractive formula structure with annual true-ups effective June 1 of each year, capturing rate base additions and OMS escalations on a very timely basis. The majority of EU's increased transmission spending is recoverable under the formula rate structure and they are added incentives for our Susquehanna-Roseland line. On the distribution side of our business, we're forecasting $1.5 billion of new investment, resulting from a combination of aging infrastructure, smart grid technology and more traditional CapEx.
Distribution cost are currently recovered through a base rate filing. As we have noted in the past, we are interested in pursuing alternative rate mechanisms that would provide for more timely recovery of the capital deploy. Absent this, we anticipate filing rate cases in 2012 and 2014 to recover the increasing expenditures needed to maintain customer liability and improve network efficiency. EU's CapEx profile on Slide 20 provides further information on those upcoming investments. 
We plan to increase our capital spending over the next two years before we hit an expected sustained level of capital investment, excluding the Susquehanna-Roseland transmission line. As illustrated here and shown in light green, transmission is a predominant driver of our CapEx group. The $1.9 billion in investment from 2011 to 2015 consistent of $800 million in aging infrastructure replacements, $700 million for capacity and other projects and the remaining $440 million is associated with the Susquehanna-Roseland line. 
Regarding Susquehanna-Roseland, the environmental review of the project by the National Park Service is going. After which, we expect construction to resume in 2013 and 2014 with the project and service early 2015. The need for this project has been reaffirmed several times by PGM, and we expect the need for the project will continue to be reaffirmed. We do not expect the recent legislation in New Jersey and associated generation projects to eliminate the need for this line.
In summary, our capital investment opportunities  and distribution translate into an annualized rate base growth of 10%. Over the same period, transmission rate base growth at just over 20%. From 28% to 40% of total rate case, increasing the proportion of our earnings driven by the transmission formula rate structure. 
Let's move on to Slide 22 and take a closer look at our competitive supply segment. We've discussed this segment and its investments highlights with you in great detail on the past and today I'll provide a brief update. Importantly, we want to highlight our ability to control spending and optimize our operations during low commodity cycles and our ability to meet and benefit from evolving EPA regulations. 
Slide 23 details the environmental control equipment we've already installed on our fleet and the control equipment under consideration. Approximately 40% of annual output from the fleet is carbon free, nuclear and hydro while approximately 50% of our output is coal-fired, the majority of our coal plants are large supercritical plants that are well controlled from an environmental perspective and highly efficient. Our proactive approach to environmental compliance positions the PPL fleet favorably for future EPA regulation. 96% of the competitive coal generation is scrub, 88% has not control already installed. 
Since 2005, PPL's invested $1.6 billion in environmental control equipment, positioning it very well for many of the proposed EPA regulations. The additional control equipment that is under consideration can be installed at an expected cost of just $350 million to $400 million. At this low point in the commodity cycle, we are clearly focused on controlling our cost. We did reduced our 2010 capital spending by nearly $100 million compared to our original plan and we've reduced our five-year plan by nearly $500 million. We're also focused on managing operating cost. We cut $30 million out of our operating budgets in both '10 and '11 despite the addition of new environmental control equipment in compliance with new security and work our regulations at our nuclear stations. We've been operating our coal units at minimum output levels during certain off-peak hours and are working to achieve even lower minimum levels. In order to reduce fuel cost, we continue to analyze the types of fuel we're bringing at each of our units. For example, we're continuing to prepare several units to burn powder river basin coal, as well as Illinois based. And we look to burn of-speck coals during off-peak periods as another means to reduce cost.
We've maintained our disciplined three-year hedging program, which is captured significant value for shareholders. The hedging program added $700 million to our margins in 2010 and our hedges for '11 and '12 are in the money by $1.4 billion. While we're unable to completely eliminate volatility in this business, our hedging strategy had significantly reduce the substantial portion of that volatility. On this slide, we're preparing our asset hedge positions for 2011 and 2012. There are a few notable changes to this slide, I'd like to point out from previous quarters. We've eliminated the base fully loaded hedged price and instead provided the annual capacity revenue separately at the bottom of this slide. This provides more visibility on our expected PGM capacity revenues. 
As we discussed previously, given current market conditions and transmission work in the region, our forecast for 2011 does not include a basis premium over PJM West Hub for units. We are also giving a range for delivered coal prices in the East and now provide you with a range of our expected coal price in the West as well. As for 2013, we continue to be very lightly hedged with less than 10% of our PJM generation under contract. We do, however, have about 80% of our coal under contract for 2013. When we enter into a more meaningful level of energy hedges for 2013, we'll provide you an update.
In 2010, we began to see signs of economic recovery and annual net energy requirements within PGM increased nearly 3% from 2009. This is roughly equivalent to the output of a 2,200 megawatt nuclear plant. PGM forecast a similar level of increased demand over the next few years. At the same time, low current foreign crisis and the uncertainty that New Jersey and Maryland are adding to future capacity, there is little incentive to add new generation. We have anticipate the return of demand will drive forward market prices higher, as well as the impact of EPA's proposed regulations affecting the supply side of the equation. 
Our internal modeling estimates that approximately 12 gigawatts of generation could be retired within PJM by 2013. This assumes all control unit less than 200 megawatts are retired along with some inefficient uncontrolled units greater than 200 megawatts. Analysis by the group, Credit Suisse and others have made similar assumptions and project retirements somewhat higher than our own analysis. The impact of those retirement should improve energy and capacity prices over the longer term.
Now before turning the call over to Paul, I'd like to conclude with the following. The new PPL, with the addition of the Kentucky regulated segment, has a very strong group of regulated businesses. These utilities will provide a significant platform of growth for a regulated earnings well into the future. The leaders of this businesses clearly understand the importance of continuing our tradition of working with regulators to ensure reliable service while providing shareholders with solid returns. 
As I mentioned in my opening comments, we're forecasting a compound annual growth rate of 9.5% and rate base. Over the next five years, PPL will be investing more than $11 billion in our delivery business in the U.S. and the U.K. Importantly, of this $11 billion, we expect 55% or $6.4 billion will be recoverable using the realtime mechanisms in the U.K., Kentucky and under our formula REITs. We believe this clearly differentiates PPL from others in our sector.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Paul.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Let's turn to Slide 28 to review our financial results for 2010. Our earnings from ongoing operations for the quarter and year reflects the earnings contribution of our Kentucky regulated segment due to the successful
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everyone. Let's turn to Slide 28 to review our financial results for 2010. Our earnings from ongoing operations for the quarter and year reflects the earnings contribution of our Kentucky regulated segment due to the successful close of the transaction on November 1. 
For the full year 2010, we earned $3.13 per share, exceeding the $2.87 per share midpoint of our 2010 forecast of earnings per share from ongoing operations. The two largest contributors of our performance versus forecast for the quarter would be the operating earnings from Kentucky of $0.12 per share and several tax items that net benefited the quarter by just about $0.12 per share. On a segment basis, we fully allocated dilution from the equity units, which was incorporated into our forecast, resulting in a $0.07 per share net contribution from Kentucky for the quarter.
The tax items that net benefited the quarter included a positive impact from evaluation adjustment for Pennsylvania net operating loss carry forwards and the negative impact of bonus depreciation, a decrease to section $1.99 deduction both of which impacted supply, as well as the negative tax impact of the tax restructuring that took place in international. 
I'll review the segment earnings drivers for 2010 and then discuss our earnings forecast for 2011. Turning to Slide 29, our international regulated segment earned $0.53 per share in 2010, a $0.19 per share decrease from 2009. This performance was the net result of higher delivery revenue, primarily driven by higher prices, which were effective April 1, 2010, under DPCR5; higher pension expense; higher interest expense, primarily due to the GBP 400 million debt issuance in March of 2010; and higher interest expense on WPD's inflation index bond on the back of higher inflation later in the year; the favorable impact of currency exchange rates; higher income taxes; and dilution of $0.07 per share. 
Moving to Slide 30, our Pennsylvania regulated segment earned $0.27 per share in 2010, an $0.08 decline compared to 2009. This decrease was the net result of higher O&M expenses, primarily due to expanded vegetation management activities and higher staffing costs, lower interest expense due to lower average debt balances, higher depreciation and dilution of $0.03 per share. 
Turning to supply. The supply segment earned $2.27 per share in 2010, an increase of $1.39 per share compared to last year, driven by significantly higher realized sales prices for our eastern base low generation, lower margins unload following agreements due to customer migration and the economic downturn and higher average fuel costs and higher energy margins in the West, primarily due to higher net sales prices partially offset by lower sales volumes.
2010 was also impacted by higher O&M primarily on our Susquehanna nuclear station as a result of the Unit 1 force outage in the third quarter, higher refueling outage cost and higher payroll cost. Higher depreciation driven by the Brunner Island's scrubbers and replacement in service in 2009, lower income taxes primarily due to the release of deferred tax valuation allowances related to the DA net operating loss carryforwards, I just mentioned and the impact of investment tax credits for the whole Wooden Rainbow hydro expansion project. 
Discontinued operations, which include operating results for the Long Island generation and the main hydros and the pending sale of Upark, equities and PPL's equity interest in Safe Harbor, as well as dilution of $0.33 per share. 
Turning to Slide 32. As Jim already mentioned, we are announcing our 2011 earnings forecast of $2.40 to $2.50 per share with the midpoint of $2.50 per share. This slide provides an overview of the key factors expected to impact 2011 earnings. A significant earning driver between 2010 and 2011 is dilution of $0.34 per share, reflecting a full year's impact of 103 million of shares of common equity issued in June 2010 to finance the Kentucky acquisition. The full year addition of our Kentucky regulated business is the largest positive driver of 2011 earnings followed by increased delivery margins in our Pennsylvania regulated segment, resulting from PPL Electrics already approved distribution rate increase that became effective January 1 of this year. 
Offsetting these positive earnings drivers are lower supply margins, which are the net result of lower electricity prices, including lower basis and capacity prices in the eastern higher fuel costs in the East and West, partially offsetting these unfavorable factors are higher expected generation and higher margins on load volume agreements. We expect higher O&M in our supply segment primarily due to increased outage cost at our fossil plants in the East and West, higher income taxes primarily in the supply segment due to the 2010 release and deferred tax valuation allowances and a lower Section 199 benefit. Lower earnings as a result of 2010 sale of non-core generating assets, higher depreciation in our supply in Pennsylvania regulated segments and higher financing cost due to higher commitment fees and higher debt levels, including a full year of interest on the equity units that we issued in June.
In addition, when excluding the impact of dilution, which is captured the single driver on this slide, we expect flat earnings in our international regulated segment driven by higher delivery revenue and a more favorable currency exchange rate offset by higher income taxes, higher depreciation and higher financing costs. 
On Slide 33, we've detailed our 2010 free cash flow from operations before dividends. The 2010 free cash flow before dividends includes the operating results of the Kentucky regulated segment, but not the cash used in the acquisition of these assets.
Since last quarter, the most significant change in the 2010 free cash flow before dividends is the expected timing of the proceeds from the pending sale of Law Review part and our interest in Safe Harbor. We now expect to close that transaction and receive the proceeds in 2011. The change in cash from operations for 2010 is the net result of a return of third-party collateral, an increase on unbilled revenue and the impact of bonus tax depreciation. 
In addition to adding asset sale proceeds to 2011, the 2011 pretty cash flow before dividend is driven by higher expected cash from operations, primarily due to a full-year impact of the Kentucky operating results; the cash benefit of bonus tax depreciation; and an expected income tax refund in 2011, which are expected to be partially offset by large pension contributions, both domestically and international and for the return of collateral to third parties. This positive cash from operations is expected to be partially offset by large capital expenditure programs in all segments.
Turning to Slide 34. As Jim mentioned earlier, we continue to focus on our dividend as a key element of total share in return. Our significantly more rate regulated business mix provides strong support for the current dividend and for future dividend growth. As depicted on this chart, regulated earnings alone nearly covered the current dividend. As a regulated earnings grow, we would expect to be able to enhance stimulating growth profile. 
Now moving to Slide 35. We're looking forward to 2012 and 2013. We expect higher domestic rate regulated earnings due to higher rate basis, directly tied to large capital expenditure programs and assumptions related to plan base rate filings during this period. Increasing distribution revenue at WPD is set during the 2009 DPCR5 process, lower supply margin as a result of depressed energy prices in our hitch profile, higher O&M in all business segment, positive fundamentals affecting the supply segment that Bill previously discussed, including E*TRADE expansion, increase load as the economy begins to recover. And with that, this concludes the prepared remarks for this morning. I'll turn the call back to Jim for Q&A.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Operator, we're ready for calls.
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. Operator, we're ready for calls.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from the line of Greg Gordon of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Your first question comes from the line of Greg Gordon of Morgan Stanley.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: First on the, it looks like overall capital expenditures at regulated utilities across all the different businesses as it pertains to rate base growth is up, but it's down in Pennsylvania and up in Kentucky. So overall, given you have automatic great writ
componenttext: First on the, it looks like overall capital expenditures at regulated utilities across all the different businesses as it pertains to rate base growth is up, but it's down in Pennsylvania and up in Kentucky. So overall, given you have automatic great writers for a lot of those debt spending in Kentucky where as you have more regulatory lag in Pennsylvania, should it be fair to assume that the overall return on equity at your regulated utilities should be rising over the next period?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's a fair statement. When you factor in that pattern that you mentioned, as well as the timing of expected rate cases in both Kentucky and Pennsylvania and the expected earned returns in the intervening years, yes.
componenttext: That's a fair statement. When you factor in that pattern that you mentioned, as well as the timing of expected rate cases in both Kentucky and Pennsylvania and the expected earned returns in the intervening years, yes.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Looking at your guidance for earnings per share for Kentucky in '11, I'm presuming that assumes that all the leverage associated with the transaction is allocated there. But even sort of assessing that out, it's like your one ROE there implied by your gui
componenttext: Looking at your guidance for earnings per share for Kentucky in '11, I'm presuming that assumes that all the leverage associated with the transaction is allocated there. But even sort of assessing that out, it's like your one ROE there implied by your guidance is high-single digits. So it's a very top of the authorized ROE in Kentucky, is that accurate or inaccurate?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's accurate. Again, driven by the capital expenditures that we will wait for recovery on. The fact that the past year that was used was a backward looking Kentucky and it goes back to September the prior year. We did see very meaningful increases in w
componenttext: That's accurate. Again, driven by the capital expenditures that we will wait for recovery on. The fact that the past year that was used was a backward looking Kentucky and it goes back to September the prior year. We did see very meaningful increases in weather-adjusted load in Kentucky in 2010. So that level of earned return is also significantly driven by continuation of that pattern. So we've been I think appropriate on our estimate of what the load is going to look like. But to the extent we see any major improvement that will help offset that. And again as you mentioned all leverage that does include the full year allocation of the equity units as well. But not just the whole coal leverage and what we put that call as replaced intercompany stock back to eon but the equity unit financing as well. It's fully been allocated against that segment.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: So if we continue to see industrial load recovery in Kentucky -- you've been, the presumption you just stated is that you are assuming the deceleration in the industrial load recovery in Kentucky in that segment, is that fair?
componenttext: So if we continue to see industrial load recovery in Kentucky -- you've been, the presumption you just stated is that you are assuming the deceleration in the industrial load recovery in Kentucky in that segment, is that fair?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's fair because they're basically above pre-recessionary levels at this point. So to the extent that we can see continued demand for the sectors that segment serves in terms of industrial, that will be the single biggest driver. But the recovery was s
componenttext: That's fair because they're basically above pre-recessionary levels at this point. So to the extent that we can see continued demand for the sectors that segment serves in terms of industrial, that will be the single biggest driver. But the recovery was so strong in late '09 and '10 that will be tough to see that continuing at that pace. Industrial loads were up almost 19% last year.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: So that will be a factor in whether you exceed that number a big piece of it will be watching the economy in Kentucky?
componenttext: So that will be a factor in whether you exceed that number a big piece of it will be watching the economy in Kentucky?

componenttext: Yes, in my mind that would be that and whatever success we can achieve as it relates to find ways to operate the combined businesses more effectively and efficiently.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jim, I'm not going to ask you anything directly with regard to M&A since you clearly don't already indicated you won't answer it. But what are the criteria that you're looking at if you were to pursue another acquisition? I think as investors look at what
componenttext: Jim, I'm not going to ask you anything directly with regard to M&A since you clearly don't already indicated you won't answer it. But what are the criteria that you're looking at if you were to pursue another acquisition? I think as investors look at what you've done here, you've been very aggressive in trying to achieve your strategic goals of moving the needle of the business mix. From my perspective, one of the great asset. But you did a very large financing to finance that. I think as investors look at the profile I think the feeling that they'd like to see execution on integrating what you've done and so much that you might come back to them and ask for more money for another acquisition so soon. So as you think about those things and you think about the opportunities that exist that out there, what are the criteria that would have to be met for you have something but comment specifically on the transaction?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Greg, the scenario you've laid out I think is I agree with is very accurate. And I think I'd say two words that remain in my mind for a consideration of a path to growing shareholder value. In the first word would be strategic, meaning I wo
componenttext: Well, I think, Greg, the scenario you've laid out I think is I agree with is very accurate. And I think I'd say two words that remain in my mind for a consideration of a path to growing shareholder value. In the first word would be strategic, meaning I would approach that innovating that matches the strategy that we've laid out to our shareholders. And the second I think, more important word as to where we stand today in executing that strategy is accretive. So I think that those are two key words that I think any share owner of any company that would find itself assessing where PPL has been over the past few years would find logical.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Asshar Khan of Lissium Asset Management.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ashar, there was a partial year impact of dilution that affected 2010 because the shares were issued in June. The 30-plus cents that's on the slide on the walk from '10 to '11 represents the balance of the year impact to get the full weighted average amou
componenttext: Ashar, there was a partial year impact of dilution that affected 2010 because the shares were issued in June. The 30-plus cents that's on the slide on the walk from '10 to '11 represents the balance of the year impact to get the full weighted average amount of shares up from basically $390-ish million to $490 million. And then '10 was the $0.43 that we initially announced, which was $0.38 from the shares, a nickel from the equity converts was offset by -- it was actually slightly larger because we outperform planned, but it was offset by the $0.12 that we earned from the segment itself in November and December.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: One thing, and I'm not sure I fully just based on your hesitation that I fully answered your last question. I would say that we do not see much dilution in 2011 at all from the Kentucky acquisition. If I phrase it that way, we do not see meaningful diluti
componenttext: One thing, and I'm not sure I fully just based on your hesitation that I fully answered your last question. I would say that we do not see much dilution in 2011 at all from the Kentucky acquisition. If I phrase it that way, we do not see meaningful dilution in 2010 from having done the deal, given where commodity prices have moved, given where we see the earnings opportunities and other segment, it's not a significant number.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, your math is definitely off.
componenttext: Yes, your math is definitely off.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: When the bonus depreciation -- again, I know all the other companies have already talked about this. The IRS is still developing, either regulation or rev fox around interpreting committee reports on what was intended and what the results will be. But we
componenttext: When the bonus depreciation -- again, I know all the other companies have already talked about this. The IRS is still developing, either regulation or rev fox around interpreting committee reports on what was intended and what the results will be. But we see somewhere around $700 million between the September 9, 2010 implementation and the end of '12 when its around $700 million in total cash benefit during that period versus what things would have looked like without the bonus depreciation. Now in a full year like 2011, yes it's nice that FFO, it helps credit metrics, it's cash. We'll likely push out the need for equity at least to the very back into the year. The net impact though on earnings is still a negative, since we were in a position where we should have gotten around the nickel to $0.06 to Section 199 benefit, the manufacturers deduction that affects both the Kentucky and Pennsylvania base competitive generation, Montana generation. So all in all, it's a net negative from an earnings perspective, slightly including the impact of pushing back equity financing needs. However, it does provide significant cash surplus. So our cash benefit.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say negative by about $0.02 to $0.03, maybe.
componenttext: No, I'd say negative by about $0.02 to $0.03, maybe.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Asshar, it's Bill Spence. We would not expect anything significantly from the last auction. Perhaps a slightly higher number because it speaks to the CONE that have been made. Of course that's absent any impact to the New Jersey legislation or from that,
componenttext: Asshar, it's Bill Spence. We would not expect anything significantly from the last auction. Perhaps a slightly higher number because it speaks to the CONE that have been made. Of course that's absent any impact to the New Jersey legislation or from that, we do expect that the company's, including PPL that have filed a pleading in court and with PJM's expected response, we think we will be successful at requiring any new generation in New Jersey to be bidding at hopefully CONE and that would certainly mitigate some of the potential impact that could otherwise come out of that. So I would say absent New Jersey, maybe a slight improvement compared to the last auction.

componenttext: Customer migration continues about 50% of the customer load has switched to a third-party supplier. However, there is no net impact on PPL for two reasons. One is, it's obviously a pass-through at the electric utility business unit and as it relates to our competitive supply, we do not have any significant load filing positions in Pennsylvania under any load filing contracts, including PPL Electric Utilities.

componenttext: Back into the fourth quarter, at least back that far. Remember that we do have a reason of full amount of normal drip between drip and management of $100 million. So what I'm talking about is that incremental kind of 250-ish that I mentioned EEI. So the other stuff will turn out as we pay dividend.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just I guess, Jim, what's your expectation this EPA go full speed ahead does success in trying to range in the pacer how you see things as you start to come up to March?
componenttext: And then just I guess, Jim, what's your expectation this EPA go full speed ahead does success in trying to range in the pacer how you see things as you start to come up to March?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we're all following obviously the politics of the entire EPA situation. The way I think about it is that there will be some hesitance or a little slower going forward then back we expected a year ago. But I think it's important to realize that the
componenttext: I think we're all following obviously the politics of the entire EPA situation. The way I think about it is that there will be some hesitance or a little slower going forward then back we expected a year ago. But I think it's important to realize that there are certain things that EPA is mandated to do and we'll have to complete their regulations on and their rulings. And so I tend to think that much of the intent of their regulations will become evident through this calendar year, either by laying them out in great clarity or enough information on the table to know that they will happen. So I think our view has been looking at our fleets and our level of economic spend that we've already accomplished on our generating fleets. We stand to be in a very good position going forward and that we've already spent the money and spent it at the right time. We in fact will benefit from additional small coal unit shutdowns, as I think Bill mentioned, our supercritical fleet here out West and Kentucky, obviously that will be recovered under the ECR. But in our merchant markets in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, were positioned very well for the EPA regs as we see them unfolding. But I do think to try to answer your question, I see a bit of a delay, but I don't see them going away by a long shot.

componenttext: The deferred tax release that you mentioned, could you just elaborate a little more on that in your what ballpark that you're talking about in 2011?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have a substantial amount of Pennsylvania net operating loss carry forward at energy supply and energy funding that based upon historical record of not showing profitability at that entity, we had to reserve it again. It simply muted being realizable.
componenttext: We have a substantial amount of Pennsylvania net operating loss carry forward at energy supply and energy funding that based upon historical record of not showing profitability at that entity, we had to reserve it again. It simply muted being realizable. Last year, we released a couple of cents to earnings from that. This year, we're having the exchange more dramatically. This year was a business plan that showed significant taxable income at that entity and being able to get out from under rate caps and all the clamoring that went on through the legislators through the end of last year only a small amount of valuation allowance resulted from last year. But we're guiding the end of 2010 and completed the business plan, we just simply saw a much more robust taxable income levels that will justify using the credit. So it amounted to $0.15 to $0.17 of total, the 199 impact was a negative $0.03 and then the international tax restructuring was a negative $0.07. It's all very small ones lumpy that got to the $0.12.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Should we see any substantial tax changes passed 2011 that we should be thinking about like this?
componenttext: Should we see any substantial tax changes passed 2011 that we should be thinking about like this?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, there is an amount of deferred tax valuation allowance that remains. It's not anywhere near what was released between the combination of this year and last year. We would have to see a relatively significant improvement in power market fundamentals on
componenttext: No, there is an amount of deferred tax valuation allowance that remains. It's not anywhere near what was released between the combination of this year and last year. We would have to see a relatively significant improvement in power market fundamentals on a competitive business to see the ability to release that and positively effect the effective tax rate. So I don't see that in any significant way until we see something more positive on that front.

componenttext: That's correct. I think we originally might have planned that second or third quarter. But obviously, the need is pushed out. The cash is here and we're trying to mitigate obviously as well the negative effect of the losses of Section 199 to all these bonus depreciation that decrease of taxable income so much.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the PJM filing, you said the New Jersey legislation the 205 filing, what's the hesitation and timing of it? It's almost like we're a week since the governor signed it and you think there was a lot of operations before he sign that? Any thoughts w
componenttext: And then the PJM filing, you said the New Jersey legislation the 205 filing, what's the hesitation and timing of it? It's almost like we're a week since the governor signed it and you think there was a lot of operations before he sign that? Any thoughts when you actually see that filing?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it will be very shortly. I don't have the exact time frame. But we obviously P3, which is the group that we're involved with a lot of the larger PJM generators made its pleading. I do expect a very timely response from PJM. And I would expect the
componenttext: I think it will be very shortly. I don't have the exact time frame. But we obviously P3, which is the group that we're involved with a lot of the larger PJM generators made its pleading. I do expect a very timely response from PJM. And I would expect the market monitor to testify in support of making the necessary changes to impose a minimum offer price. And at the same time, P3 members either collectively or individually will be making federal court challenges as it relates to federal preemption and trade interference. So that will be coming probably after I would take the PJM filing of court. But it's something that's obviously important to us as generators and a big challenge to competitive markets in PJM. So we're very serious about using everything in our power to overturn this kind of threat.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011

componenttext: In the P3 filing, it mentions the subjugation that's been happening on the renewal area as being something that will be deferred to the purpose of their expedited filing but something that will be look at. Would that be something that you'd be looking at in the Federal Court in terms of building after the sort of there's a large amount of subsidy the subjugation is rolled out the power market would expect certain part of generation is there any thought about that?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm just really not sure about that. I would say that the reason we mentioned it, but at least a different level, I want to keep that out for now so we want a laser focus on just getting this issue with the 2,000 megawatts dealt with right out-of-the-box
componenttext: I'm just really not sure about that. I would say that the reason we mentioned it, but at least a different level, I want to keep that out for now so we want a laser focus on just getting this issue with the 2,000 megawatts dealt with right out-of-the-box in time for the next PJM auction. So we want to be very focused in what we're asking FERC to look at.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: We look back at what you said at the time of the Kentucky acquisition in terms of business mix and you are talking about 55% to 60% I think was the target you have for regulated and the fact that it's going to be 50/50 or so in 2011, earnings wise. Can yo
componenttext: We look back at what you said at the time of the Kentucky acquisition in terms of business mix and you are talking about 55% to 60% I think was the target you have for regulated and the fact that it's going to be 50/50 or so in 2011, earnings wise. Can you just help us think about that, do you got that naturally from further decline in the above market hedges? How do you think about that target cyclically would supply business and the range of earnings that it could have?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think going back to that first part of the comment, John, I think the 55% to 60% was kind of the EBITDA basis was only at disclosed. From a balance sheet perspective and through the commodity cycles, clearly better than 50%. But with all of the growth t
componenttext: I think going back to that first part of the comment, John, I think the 55% to 60% was kind of the EBITDA basis was only at disclosed. From a balance sheet perspective and through the commodity cycles, clearly better than 50%. But with all of the growth that we see, the shape of the commodity cycle in our hedge profile, at a midcycle number, something in the 70% to 75% feels like the right range for us to be in. If we get to 80%, if it went to as low as 70% that wouldn't cost us to alter mix per say. But just in terms of being able to handle the volatility to meaningfully address the dividend over time, provide the transparency and growth, that feels like the right kind of midcycle mix to us.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: The 75%, is the right number midcycle?
componenttext: The 75%, is the right number midcycle?

componenttext: I'd say probably you're going to get out to that 14, 15 timeframe would be my guess. headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering what do you see for the longer-term in terms of pay-out ratio? And also what are your sort of cap structure goes, given the larger portion of the business that you will have?
componenttext: I was just wondering what do you see for the longer-term in terms of pay-out ratio? And also what are your sort of cap structure goes, given the larger portion of the business that you will have?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we'll wait before. As we let the business evolve to spending and actually get through the natural rate cycles here before we come out with something on a targeted payout ratio basis. What we were trying to indicate on the dividend slide is showing
componenttext: I think we'll wait before. As we let the business evolve to spending and actually get through the natural rate cycles here before we come out with something on a targeted payout ratio basis. What we were trying to indicate on the dividend slide is showing that in combining this response with how I responded to Jonathan's question. We're very clearly be able to more than sufficiently to cover the dividend with the regulated earnings. I think it depends upon where we see midcycle gas prices driving power, which drives margins and maintaining our three-year hedge profile. I think it's difficult until we get up into that 75-ish percentage range. And I feel comfortable talking about payout ratios. We're getting through the last part of our generation build around the Susquehanna operation, the Holtwood and Rainbow construction project and given to more of a normalized level of maintenance CapEx spend as well.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in terms of capital structure, you're planning on does issue at year end and do you think that you will have because of the expansion that you're planning on, do think that in two years, you will be issuing equity?
componenttext: And in terms of capital structure, you're planning on does issue at year end and do you think that you will have because of the expansion that you're planning on, do think that in two years, you will be issuing equity?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Again that is part of commodity. I'll clearly say, that that's a safe bet. If the regulated utilities are kind of fully paying for the dividend and the generation business is using its surplus cash flow to fund the small capital expansion projects, we've
componenttext: Again that is part of commodity. I'll clearly say, that that's a safe bet. If the regulated utilities are kind of fully paying for the dividend and the generation business is using its surplus cash flow to fund the small capital expansion projects, we've got to be able to fund that CapEx growth of the utilities in some and it will be through a balance of debt and equity. I think that that would be reasonable amount of equity, not unlike other companies that have to fund programs in this way and again what I'd say is the biggest driver there is maintaining the investment grade credit ratings that in those businesses as well supply. So that's really what drives the timing and amounts, it's the combination of the commodity cycle and the cap structure to achieve targeted credit metrics. So we'll try and limit delusions.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned your plans to the Pennsylvania commission in terms of the grid of the infrastructure?
componenttext: You mentioned your plans to the Pennsylvania commission in terms of the grid of the infrastructure?

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. We had A long series of conversations with them going back for more than a year about that we're seeing in terms of equipment, performance, reliability, degradation rates and the need to be able to achieve the service reliability level th
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. We had A long series of conversations with them going back for more than a year about that we're seeing in terms of equipment, performance, reliability, degradation rates and the need to be able to achieve the service reliability level that they've outlined for the entire subject that need to be achieved. As Bill mentioned in his prepared remarks, a lot of this equipment goes back into the 50, 60s, 70s and it's just simply reaching the end of its life. And from both the company perspective, and a customer perspective, the right decision is to not chase O&M expense to replace these old equipment. It's better for the company and it's cheaper for the customer in the long run to make that investment that it is to be chasing reliability projects.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carl Felixson of Utility Financial Expert.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carl Felixson of Utility Financial Expert.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we get the more, I'll call it perfect recovery in the U.K. in the first transmission so what we're really talking about what's left if you will is Pennsylvania distribution and then the Kentucky assets that not recover in the ECR in Kentucky. I
componenttext: Obviously, we get the more, I'll call it perfect recovery in the U.K. in the first transmission so what we're really talking about what's left if you will is Pennsylvania distribution and then the Kentucky assets that not recover in the ECR in Kentucky. In Pennsylvania, what I would say is that and I think Bill mentioned this in his remarks, that we have filings in our business plan in 2012 and 2014, which would result in new rates effective 1113 and 1115 on the distribution side. In Kentucky, I think when we get down into the 9% kind of ROE levels, that would historically have how we think about trigger the need for profilings there. Now we do have a committed stand from the change of control filing that we cannot file until '12 for new rates to be effective earlier than 1113. So a potential scenario is filing in both Kentucky and in full and then Pennsylvania for the D side with new rates in both effective with 113. That's a potential again based upon what happens with load and what happens with cost and our success around deficiencies in that area, being timetable as well. But that's kind of what our plan would indicate would be needed.

headline: PPL Corporation, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, operator. And thank you all for tuning on the call. I just want to make a couple of comments here as we close. One I think we're very pleased with the results of our Kentucky acquisition thus far. And I think we're pretty clear we have ac
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, operator. And thank you all for tuning on the call. I just want to make a couple of comments here as we close. One I think we're very pleased with the results of our Kentucky acquisition thus far. And I think we're pretty clear we have accomplished what we intended when you see our rev earnings jumping from 27% up to 50%. So we're certainly, moving along with our strategic direction that we've laid out to you. I think we're very pleased as we look at our potential compound annual growth rate, just shy of 10% on a regulated rate base and also the high percentage is spend in that growth rate base that will come from regulatory jurisdictions, where we eliminate a good part of the regulatory lag. So we're very encouraged by that. We've also cleaned it out I think, that we do stand to benefit basically from the EPA rigs as we see them unfolding based to some extent on our early work in our Pennsylvania fleet and our Montana condition assets and also the regulatory posture we have or structure we have in place in Kentucky. So I think with that, we feel pretty good about going forward. We seen some encouraging industrial growth in some of our regulatory regions. And I think that's what we all want to see and as this economy continues to try to recover, I think our position will strengthen there as well. And we'll see, I hope improve prices in PJM, and we'll be able to take advantage of a really good fleet and good pricing position we have in the PJM Interconnection. So with that, I thank you all for sitting in on the call and look forward to talking to you again. Thank you, operator.
